data.sampled: This option strategy is called as a vertical spread. The investor is selling a call option at a higher strike price and buying a call option at a lower strike price, both with the same expiration date. This results in a net credit, allowing the investor to profit from a relatively small market move in the underlying stock but still cap the upside potential by selling the higher call.

data.sampled:
Based on the given setup, if the stock price increases above the strike price of the long call, the maximum potential profit is limited to the difference between the exercise prices of the long and short options. In this case, the long call strike price is $280 and the short call strike price is $265. Therefore, if the stock price increases above $280, the call buyer will exercise the long option and the short call option will be exercised and will result in a net profit. If the stock price does not increase above $280, the call options will have a net value of zero.

Based on this information, it can be assumed that a decrease in the stock price will result in losses of the same magnitude. Therefore, an increase in the stock price is more optimal for the given position.
